message_1: Let X be a non-empty set and let τ = {∅, X} be the trivial topology on X. Determine whether the set S = {x} is open or closed in the topological space (X, τ), where x ∈ X.
message_2:
In the trivial topology τ = {∅, X}, a set is considered open if it is either the empty set or the entire set X. The set S = {x} is neither the empty set nor the entire set X, so it is not open in the topological space (X, τ).

A set is considered closed if its complement is open. The complement of S = {x} is X - {x}, which is the set of all elements in X except for x. If X has more than one element, then X - {x} is neither the empty set nor the entire set X, so it is not open, and therefore S = {x} is not closed.

However, if X has exactly one element, i.e., X = {x}, then X - {x} = ∅, which is open in the trivial topology. In this case, S = {x} is closed.

In summary, the set S = {x} is neither open nor closed in the topological space (X, τ) when X has more than one element, but it is closed when X has exactly one element.
